metadata.sermon_start_end: A few days ago, as I was beginning to think about this sermon for Trinity Sunday, I heard an agnostic friend refer to the activity of the Christian church as “proselytizing.” [...] In him there is news so good that we cannot possibly keep it to ourselves, for he has gone before us with the Great Commission to all the peoples of the earth, and lo, Jesus is with us always, even to the end of the world. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Matthew 28:18-20 as a springboard for a topical discussion on 'evangelism' versus 'proselytism' and 'multiculturalism'. It fails to identify what is unique to THIS passage that cannot be found elsewhere. Instead, it treats the text as a 'strategic' summary of general Christian mission.
quotes: These words of our Lord are found in a strategic place, for they are the concluding words of the first book of the New Testament
They are words in which Jesus turns over the good news about himself to the church.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the specific Matthean vocabulary (e.g., 'making disciples', 'observing all I commanded') rather than general concepts of 'good news' found throughout the NT.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no historical-critical or linguistic exegesis. The mention of the Greek word 'evangel' is a general etymological observation, not an exposition of Matthew's specific theology or the context of the post-resurrection appearance in Galilee.
quotes: The word evangel is a New Testament Greek word, lying at the heart and center of our faith.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the original context: why Galilee? What did 'nations' (ethne) mean to a first-century Jewish-Christian audience? Move beyond dictionary definitions.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part of the sermon. It engages specifically with the 1993 New York zeitgeist, mentioning Arthur Schlesinger, Billy Graham rallies in Central Park, and the tension between multiculturalism and Christian testimony.
quotes: In the meantime, back here in New York, we are part of the most multicultural society on earth
Historian Arthur Schlesinger worries about the current tendencies wherein 'the new ethnic gospel... rejects the unifying vision'
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the specific text's constraints rather than from a general sociological observation about New York.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is more of a thematic essay than an interwoven exposition. The text is cited, then the preacher moves into anecdotes and cultural philosophy. The 'hearer' is drawn into the preacher's experiences (William on Fourth Avenue) more than into the biblical text itself.
quotes: Here is a little parable of multicultural Christianity. Many of you know William, who more or less lives on my doorstep on Fourth Avenue.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Use the biblical text as the primary lens through which the contemporary situation is viewed, rather than using the situation to illustrate a general biblical idea.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories are present, particularly 'misery' (the 'dirt' of human condition and broken relationships) and 'redemption' (Christ assuming the dirt). However, it leans toward a psychological/sociological interpretation of misery rather than a strictly theological one before God.
quotes: What’s the second secret ingrediment, then? It’s D-I-R-T. Not just William’s dirt, but my dirt, your dirt...
In Christ, we are washed clean and made into a new fellowship
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by connecting it to the 'all power' of Jesus—why does man need a Lord with all authority? Address the rebellion against that authority.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon explicitly rejects the 'bad news' of being lost or the threat of judgment. It emphasizes inclusion to the point that the 'narrow way' is obscured. The 'two ways' are replaced by a 'multicultural logjam' being broken.
quotes: Proselytizing sounds like bad news to me, and who wants to hear that?
The Christian gospel is infinitely more radical and more inclusive than anything you or I would dream up.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the gravity of the 'Great Commission'—if there is no danger of being lost (temporal or eternal), the command to 'teach all nations' loses its urgency and necessity.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, and the doctrine of the Trinity is defended as an 'event'. However, Christ is presented primarily as the one who facilitates 'relationships' and 'cleansing', rather than the Sovereign Lord of the text who possesses 'all power'.
quotes: The Trinity has happened among us. The incarnation of Jesus Christ... is good news for every person
All the dirt was assumed by God himself in the person of his Son
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect the person of Christ more directly to the 'authority' (exousia) mentioned in Matthew 28:18.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1950 words, the sermon likely clocks in just under the 20-minute threshold required for 'depth' according to Dekker. It prioritizes breadth of anecdotes over depth of textual exegesis.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Reduce the number of cultural anecdotes (Pogo, Schlesinger, personal friends) to allow for more 'breadth' in the actual exposition of the Scripture passage.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon fails Dekker's primary formal requirement: it is a speech about 'the gospel' and 'multiculturalism' rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It avoids the 'two ways' and the seriousness of being lost, opting for a message of universal inclusion. While it is strong in its contemporary application and cultural awareness, it lacks the exegetical rigor and textual specificity Dekker demands.
strengths: Concrete contemporary application to the New York context
Effective use of the humanities (history, sociology) to engage the zeitgeist
Clear Trinitarian framework for understanding relationships
weaknesses: Lack of specific exegesis of the Matthew 28 text
Absence of the 'two ways' or the seriousness of judgment
Thematic/topical approach rather than textual exposition
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate religious address but, according to Dekker's strict definition, it is not a sermon. It treats the Bible passage as a pretext for a general discussion on mission and society, failing to recreate the specific written Word into a new, current, proclamatory word unique to that text.
